column4: I noticed my computer rebooted at during the night. I didn't reboot it, and no one has any legitimate access to the machine. Is there any possibility this doesnt indicate a compromise? (recent ssh vuln makes me believe this scenario isnt unlikely)
I don't see anything suspicious in the .bash_history.
they still on your machine? type who in terminal to see
nope, only me, I assume they rebooted to cover their tracks
so, this really must mean someone else was on the machine right? I don't know anything that can restart your machine without user intervention
unless it was scheduled by you; who else had access to the machine and knew your pass
no one else has access. I looked through auth.log, and syslog. I don't see anything obviously wrong :-/.
when did you see it restarted? could it have been a power spike?
this morning, could a power spike have triggered a soft restart? The OS detect the power spike the restart on its own, or is that not likely?
just trying to cover all possibilities
yep thanks. I'm not sure what the appropriate response is here... reinstall OS? What steps can i take to check whether there was really a compromise (or is the restart itself enough evidence?)
that seems over much; do you use ssh-server?
yep, and i had it unpached for about 8 hours on Tuesday
well get the updates, generate some new keys first off
done and done =)
: ok, i think i may have jumped the gun. It was actually gdm that restarted (potentially crashed?), the machine did /not/ reboot. The restart I was looking at the syslogd daemon restarting =)
ah that is good news; best to get new keys and update though right?
thanks for your help. time to relax a bit after this mild heart attack
what do you need to do
#ubuntu+1 for 8.10
then go to ##windows
